subject: News Summary
body:
CBSNews.com






May 9, 2007


                              		
                              		
                              	  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video



                              	
                              	  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation






TOP STORIESBush Tours Town Wiped Out By Tornado
Stepping through the rubble, President Bush got his first look at the Kansas farming town that was nearly obliterated after
                        last week's killer tornado. The president said he hoped he could "touch somebody's soul by representing the country." More...Watch: Bush In Tornado-Struck Kansas
• Fed Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged• Cheney: Iraq Still A Dangerous Place
                     					| Watch• Failing Levees Spur Major Missouri Floods
                     					| WatchU.S.Indictment In 1965 Civil Rights Killing
An Alabama grand jury has returned a sealed indictment in the 1965 shooting death of a black man by a state trooper during
                        a melee at a civil rights demonstration.   More...
• Woman Sentenced For Antifreeze Murder• Report: Sosa, Palmeiro In Steroid Probe• Fort Dix Plot Called "New" Form Of Terror
                     					| Watch• More StoriesWorldCuba And Venezuela: U.S. Shields Terrorist
Venezuela and Cuba have accused Washington of shielding a terrorist after a judge threw out immigration fraud charges against
                        a man wanted in the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner. More...
• Cheney: Iraq Still A Dangerous Place
                     					| Watch• Blair To Announce Plans For Future • 4 Arrested For 2005 U.K. Bombings• More StoriesPoliticsWhite House Vows Another Iraq Veto
The White House said President Bush would veto the Democrats' latest version of the Iraq war funding bill. The measure would
                        provide funds for the war only through July, then give Congress the option to cut off money if conditions do not improve. More...
• Bush Tours Town Wiped Out By Tornado
                     					| Watch• Maryland Governor Endorses Hillary Clinton• Sharpton Denies Questioning Romney's Faith• More StoriesHealthWeekend Births Riskier In Some Hospitals
Giving birth on a weekend may be riskier to a newborn's life if relatively few babies are delivered at the hospital, according
                        to a new Texas study. More...
• China Makes Arrests In Pet Food Case• Women Suffer In Silence With ADHD• Study: Baby Aspirin Best For Heart• More StoriesSciTechSubtropical Storm Forms Off Atlantic Coast
Subtropical Storm Andrea formed off the southeastern U.S. coast, more than three weeks before the official start of hurricane
                        season, forecasters said. Subtropical systems are hybrid weather formations that are usually weaker than tropical storms. More...
• Cheap Power For Northeast A Mixed Blessing• Australia Uses Aboriginal Weather Wisdom • Comcast Unveils Super-Fast Modem• More StoriesBusinessFed Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
The Federal Reserve left a key interest rate unchanged as the economy signaled that it was on track for a soft landing in
                        which growth slows enough to restrain inflation. More...
• Scholarship Tips For High School Students• Gas Station Owner Ordered To Raise Prices• "Trigger Lists" Spur Privacy Worries
                     					| Watch• More StoriesEntertainment"Georgia Rule" Controversy Haunts Lohan
On Tuesday, producer James G. Robinson said the letter he sent Lindsay Lohan last year after she missed a day of work on the
                        film "Georgia Rule" served its purpose at the time. "She's a great actress," he said. More...Watch: Producer Explains Lohan Letter
• O.J. Tossed From Steakhouse On Derby Eve• Diaz Doesn't Worry About Seeing Her Ex• Mirren Declines Queen's Dinner Invitation
                     					| Watch• More StoriesOpinionTenet Chose Power Over Honor
George Tenet now says the case he built for war was taken out of context. So why didn't he resign in protest if the U.S. was
                        invading Iraq for no reason? The New Republic writes that, in government at least, it's the American way. More...Watch: Tenet: 'We Were Wrong'   
• Pelosi Breaks Her Promise On Pork• Elizabeth II And George II• Why '08 Will Belong To The Democrats
                     					| Watch• More StoriesCBS NEWS BROADCASTSThe Early Show: Sen. Graham's Secret Mission In Iraq
While Congress continues to debate about how to proceed with the controversial war in Iraq, only one Senator, Lindsay Graham,
                        R-S.C., has had first-hand experience in Iraq as an active-duty member of the military. More...Watch: Eye To Eye: Lindsey Graham
• EARLY SHOW: "Trigger Lists" Spur Privacy Worries

Coffee Roasting Goes GreenBrothers David and Mike Hartkop of Pueblo, Colo., have invented a coffee roaster that uses the rays of the sun. Their customers
                                    say the Joe tastes better than ever. Jennifer Miller reports.
